user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Unlock_Global:
```c
void OS_Unlock_Global(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_objtype_state_t *objtype;

    if (token->obj_type < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER && token->lock_mode != OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        objtype = &OS_objtype_state[token->obj_type];

        /*
         * Un-track ownership of this table.  It should only be owned by one
         * task at a time, and this aids in recovery if the owning task is
         * deleted or experiences an exception causing it to not be freed.
         *
         * This is done before unlocking, while this has exclusive access
         * to the state object.
         */
        if ((objtype->owner_key.key_value & 0xFF000000) != OS_LOCK_KEY_FIXED_VALUE ||
            objtype->owner_key.key_value != token->lock_key.key_value)
        {
            /* this is almost certainly a bug */
            OS_DEBUG("ERROR: global %u released using mismatched key=0x%lx expected=0x%lx\n",
                     (unsigned int)token->obj_type, (unsigned long)token->lock_key.key_value,
                     (unsigned long)objtype->owner_key.key_value);
        }

        objtype->owner_key = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID;
        token->lock_key    = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID;

        OS_Unlock_Global_Impl(token->obj_type);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("ERROR: cannot unlock global %u for mode %u\n", (unsigned int)token->obj_type,
                 (unsigned int)token->lock_mode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 14.3 applies to controlling expressions (if/while/for/do-while). The only controlling expressions in this function are the two if-statements listed above; there are no loops or other conditional operators in the function. Other lines are assignments, function calls, or debug prints (e.g. objtype->owner_key = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID; token->lock_key = OS_LOCK_KEY_INVALID; OS_Unlock_Global_Impl(...); OS_DEBUG(...);), which are not subject to Rule 14.3. Therefore no additional fragments need investigation.
